snippet: Long angered by allegations of U.S. spying, Germany itself was accused of espionage, including picking up conversations involving Hillary Rodham Clinton and John Kerry.
abstract: German government struggles to respond to news media reports that its intelligence services routinely spy on Turkey, a NATO ally; reports say Germany captured at least one conversation each with former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and her successor John Kerry; Turkey summons German ambassador to demand immediate investigation.

byline.original: By MELISSA EDDY and SEBNEM ARSU
byline.contributor: Melissa Eddy reported from Berlin, and Sebnem Arsu from Istanbul. Alison Smale contributed reporting from Riga, Latvia.

lead_paragraph: Long angered by allegations of U.S. spying, Germany itself was accused of espionage, including picking up conversations involving Hillary Rodham Clinton and John Kerry.

headline.main: Turkey Expresses Outrage at Reports of Routine Spying by Germany, a NATO Ally
headline.print_headline: Turkey Expresses Outrage at Reports of Routine Spying by Germany, a NATO Ally

keywords.value: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
keywords.name: subject
